Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Low cost shortwave infrared (SWIR) spectral imaging microscope camera based on Compressive Sensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to open price-sensitive research, medical imaging and surveillance communities to the benefits of the shortwave infrared (SWIR) waveband without the complexity or expense of traditional hyperspectral systems. The multispectral SWIR imager developed in this project supports medical microscope and small animal imaging of infrared fluorescence for cancer detection, localization and excision. SWIR fluorophores produce no autofluorescence background while simultaneously enhancing tissue penetration depth and efficiency by factors of 10 or more. InView?s imaging platform can build large markets by the development of specialized image processing and analytical methods for specific applications in pharmaceutical manufacturing, food safety, solar panel and semiconductor inspection, machine vision, and navigation. InView?s camera platform embodies the revolutionary new sampling theory of compressive sensing, a field whose applications in information processing have grown exponentially. The innovative architecture and the state-of-the-art software already embedded in the camera and user interface can enhance and possibly transform lab and clinical modalities in dynamic multi-fluorescence imaging, in vivo functional imaging, tissue viability and pathology studies, and advanced imaging modalities such as optical coherence tomography.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 2 project will result in an operational low-cost, multi-color shortwave infrared (SWIR) camera that can be directly mounted on microscopes for supporting compelling micro-imaging applications in scientific, industrial and biomedical imaging. The electro-optical, opto-mechanical, and processing software architecture of the camera is based on Compressive Sensing, a new sampling technique that reduces data collection requirements for high resolution imaging to well below Nyquist limits. This design does not use expensive sensor arrays or complicated spectrometers. Instead, high-resolution pictures are computationally constructed from single-detector measurements. The ?single-pixel camera? architecture was commercialized by InView as a monochromatic SWIR imager. In Phase 1, InView successfully demonstrated that only simple modifications to its monochromatic camera design can produce full color imaging. The objective of Phase 2 is to modify only the components that are necessary to transform the existing monochromatic camera into a multi-color imager with the overall design goal of maintaining the existing camera size, weight and cost so that InView can offer low-cost multispectral SWIR imaging to the price sensitive microscopy community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project was to develop and demonstrate a multi-spectral imaging capability in the compressive-sensing based single-pixel camera architecture developed by InView Technology Corporation.  InView’s innovative high-resolution digital camera platform is the first imaging device to embody a new sampling theory called compressive sensing. By acquiring data according to compressive sensing theory, images can be reconstructed accurately even when that data is grossly undersampled by traditional Nyquist standards. The benefit of this computational camera architecture is that dense pixels arrays are not needed for imaging.  This is especially important for imaging at infrared wavelengths where pixel arrays can be hundreds of times more expensive than the silicon arrays typically used in visible light cameras.  Benefits of our multi-spectral system include creating “color” images from bands of light spanning the visible, near-infrared  and shortwave infrared spectra using only a small number of detectors, each of which can be optimized independently for its particular wavelength.    

InView was able to achieve multi-spectral performance using only a few modifications to the existing monochromatic compressive camera architecture. These modifications were designed using an analytical model of the diffractive behavior of the camera’s optics combined with compressive sensing algorithms.  During this Phase II, an operational four-band camera was built and tested. The camera’s optical and electronic subsystems were integrated into a stand-alone enclosure and a user interface was developed to easily control camera settings and display images from all four channels.  Using this interface, the camera could be operated either as a network imager or by direct connection to a laptop via one Ethernet cable. Imaging was demonstrated in a number of applications including microscopy, scientific imaging in the lab, and imaging of outdoor scenes in natural light.  It was found that 4-channel compressive imaging operates as designed, verifying diffractive models and optical designs of the system. It was also found that certain design changes could improve dynamic range of the camera and improve noise performance.

The capability to combine image information from multiple wavebands spanning the visible and infrared spectra can lead to enhanced imaging in many applications. Think of how important the advent of color digital photography has been to many aspects of our lives including art, entertainment, social media, as well as in many areas of scientific exploration.  InView’s work has advanced technology for adding “colors” to digital images that the human eye cannot see but that never-the-less contain important information about the scene.  Just like red, green and blue channels of the visible spectrum combine to create a more complete picture than just black and white images, we can perceive even more information by adding bands in the near infrared to visualize moisture content and material composition that can be important in applications like grading plastics for recycling, inspecting produce, monitoring agriculture, developing pharmaceuticals, inspecting semiconductors, and differentiating tissues in the human body.

InView showed that compressive sensing allows imaging at multiple infrared wavelengths at very low additional camera cost, which can open larger markets for shortwave infrared cameras and facilitate discovery and development of applications in the shortwave infrared band. Applications include in vivo medical imaging and pathology, materials inspection, process monitoring, and surveillance.  InView’s camera can replace higher cost cameras in these applications providing multi-spectral images without sacrificing spatial resolution.  In addition, the computational aspect of the camera provides a convenient pathway for implementing machine vision algorithms for pattern recognition and classification embedded directly in the camera’s hardware.  Follow-on work includes the development of compressed domain deep learning algorithms that are trained directly on multi-spectral compressed data to detect and classify targets of interest located within the camera’s field of view without ever reconstructing an image, paving the way for use of this technology in autonomous vehicles and robotics applications.
